title: 104_hr2166
content: The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" introduces a minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations under Subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new part, titled "Minimum Tax on Certain Foreign and Foreign-Owned Corporations," establishes a minimum tax requirement for these entities. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations based on their business activities and foreign ownership. The taxable income of the corporation must be at least 90% of the applicable profit percentage applied to gross receipts. This applies to domestic corporations that are 25% foreign-owned or foreign corporations with income connected to US business, and with substantial foreign-related transactions. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on certain corporations with substantial foreign-related transactions connected to US business. An exception exists if a qualified section 482 agreement is in effect with the corporation for the taxable year. The "Fairness and Equity Tax Act of 1995" imposes a minimum tax on corporations with foreign-related transactions unless a qualified section 482 agreement is in place for the taxable year. This agreement ensures a clear reflection of taxable income from related party transactions in specific business activities. The Secretary has the discretion to enter into such agreements, which may have retroactive effects. The Secretary has the discretion to enter into qualified section 482 agreements, which may have retroactive effects for prior taxable years. If activities of a corporation cannot be categorized by the Secretary, a minimum tax is imposed. In cases where a corporation's activities cannot be categorized by the Secretary, a minimum tax of 35 percent is imposed on gross receipts from property sales or leasing. The Secretary may waive this tax in cases of casualty or disaster. Foreign taxes are not considered in determining taxable income for this section. The Secretary may waive the minimum tax of 35 percent on gross receipts from property sales or leasing in cases of casualty or disaster. Foreign taxes are not included in determining taxable income for this section. The Secretary prescribes an applicable profit percentage for different business activities based on average earnings rates of domestic corporations. The Secretary prescribes an applicable profit percentage for different business activities based on the average earnings rates of domestic corporations. This profit percentage is calculated based on the ratio of adjusted book income to gross receipts from such activities. The term 'adjusted book income' refers to income reported for financial purposes without deductions for income, war profits, or excess profits taxes. Definitions and special rules include terms like '25-percent foreign-owned' and 'substantial foreign-related person transactions' for corporations engaging in transactions with foreign parties. The IRS defines substantial foreign-related person transactions for corporations as transactions with foreign parties exceeding $2,000,000 or 10% of gross income. Business activities are categorized based on the Standard Industrial Classification Code. The IRS defines substantial foreign-related person transactions for corporations as transactions with foreign parties exceeding $2,000,000 or 10% of gross income. Business activities are categorized by reference to the 3-digit classification of the Standard Industrial Classification Code, with the Secretary having the authority to aggregate classifications where appropriate. Additionally, a classification system other than the Standard Industrial Classification Code may be used in certain cases. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Effective Date: The amendments for minimum tax on certain foreign and foreign-owned corporations apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
